King Kayanja and
 his daughter 
 
 Amana Yunus 
 English 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Long, long ago there was a king caled 
 Kayanja. He lived in a palace with the 
 
 quen and their daughter, princes 
 Apenyo. 
 
 
 Princes Apenyo was such a beautiful 
 young woman that every man wanted to 
 
 mary her. But king Kayanja demanded a 
 very high bride price for the princes. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Near king Kayanja’s palace lived a chief
 caled Aludah the Great. He was caled
 
 “the Great” because everybody in the
 neighbourhod obeyed him. (He was
 very violent to anyone who disobeyed
 
 him!) 
 
 
 Chief Aludah’s wife had recently died of
 malaria and he wanted another wife.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 2  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 So the fat old chief went to king Kayanja 
 to ofer bride wealth for the young 
 princes. 
 
 
 While the two men were discusing the 
 price, the maid Kakembo overheard their 
 
 conversation. Maid Kakembo was very 
 close to princes Apenyo. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 3  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Chief Aludah agred to give half of his
 
 wealth to king Kayanja, including a
 nedle, which was also part of the bride
 price. 
 
 
 Preparations were made in secret for the
 weding betwen chief Aludah and
 
 princes Apenyo. The king knew that his
 daughter would not be hapy with this
 
 decision. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 4  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 One wek before the royal weding day, 
 
 maid Kakembo aproached Apenyo. 
 
 “My dear princes, your father has 
 
 organised your weding with Chief 
 Aludah, and it wil take place in one 
 
 wek,” said Kakembo. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 5  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Princes Apenyo was shocked and at
 first didn’t know what to do. Then she
 thought, “I wil never mary chief Aludah,
 
 that fat old man. Never! I must hury to
 Trevor and se what he can do before it’s
 to late.” 
 
 
 Trevor was princes Apenyo’s boyfriend.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 6  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 That night Apenyo crept out of the 
 palace. If her father discovered where 
 
 she was going he would be very angry. 
 
 She ran through the thick, dark forest 
 
 over rocks and shrubs, until she finaly 
 reached her Trevor. When she arived at 
 
 his house she was tired, hungry, and 
 thirsty. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 7  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 “My love, why have you run al this long
 
 distance alone and at such a time of
 night?” asked Trevor. He fetched drinking
 water for her and alowed her to rest.
 
 
 Trevor could not setle down while he
 
 waited for Apenyo to talk. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 8  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 “My dear princes, what is the problem?” 
 asked Trevor. 
 
 
 Apenyo breathed heavily and said sadly, 
 “My father wants to mary me of to chief 
 
 Aludah the Great. But I can’t mary that 
 horible man. Trevor, I want to mary you 
 
 even if you are por. I am ready to sufer. 
 I love you.” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 9  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 “But princes, I have nothing to pay as
 your bride price, you know I’m a por
 
 boy.” cried Trevor. 
 
 Apenyo replied, “I know, but it’s only you I
 
 can get maried to.” 
 
 She thought for a while and said, “Let’s
 
 go to Katega the boat man to sail us to
 the other side of the river. That way we
 
 can escape and my father wil never find
 us.” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 10  
 
 
 
 
 
 Back at the palace, king Kayanja had 
 
 discovered Princes Apenyo’s 
 disapearance and ordered his subjects 
 
 to search for her everywhere in the 
 vilage. 
 
 
 The king’s guards, soldiers, and everyone 
 else searched, but they couldn’t find 
 Princes Apenyo. 
 
 
 They went back to the King and told him 
 
 Apenyo was nowhere to be sen. “Then 
 go to the bush and search,” King Kayanja 
 ordered. He was very anoyed. 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 As Princes Apenyo and Trevor huried to
 
 the riverbank, dark clouds began
 gathering in the sky. A heavy storm was
 coming. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 12  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Katega the boatman was moring his 
 boat when the young couple aproached 
 him. Trevor asked Katega to row them 
 
 acros the river. 
 
 Katega refused to acept, explaining 
 
 that a heavy storm was fast aproaching, 
 and it would be to dangerous. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 13  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Trevor insisted and explained to Katega
 why they must cros. He then put his
 
 hand dep in his pocket and tok out a
 cowrie shel to give to Katega.
 
 
 When Katega heard their story and saw
 the beautiful shel, he felt sory for them.
 
 He agred to row them acros the river in
 spite of the weather. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 14  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Katega puled the boat near the bank 
 and told them to get in. He then picked 
 his oars and began rowing. 
 
 
 When king Kayanja and chief Aludah 
 reached the bank, they saw the thre 
 
 people in the boat. They realised that the 
 young lovers had escaped. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 15  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Heavy winds rocked the boat and 
 Katega could no longer control it. King
 
 Kayanja shouted: “Apenyo, please come
 back! I have forgiven you and wil never
 
 punish you or Trevor.” 
 
 But it was to late. The boat tiped over
 
 and the thre people were thrown into
 the wild water. They al drowned.
 
 
 After that day, everyone in king Kayanja’s
 kingdom could mary anyone they 
 
 wanted, rich or por.
